title: Iran set for tourism rebirth as a new destination for beaches and skiing following lifting of economic sanctions
text:
View
comments
Iran's tourism industry is anticipating rapid growth following the lifting of economic sanctions.
Visits by Western travellers and investment from international hospitality firms and tourism operators are expected to rise, with foreign hotel chains already expressing interest in Iran's potential.
Buoyed by the historic nuclear deal, tour operators and hospitality companies are eyeing the destination optimistically.
Scroll down for video
Ancient enchantment: The sun sets over the ancient architecture and dramatic skyline in the city of Yadz
Diversity: Mazandaran, Terraced Hot Springs on a sunny day in Badab-e Surt Hot Springs in Mazandaran Province
UAE-based Rotana was the first international hotelier to re-enter Iran after the revolution and the group has plans to expand its footprint further with four hotel deals penned in Mashhad and Tehran.
This year French hospitality company, Accor announced plans to manage five-star Axis Prime in Tehran.
Melia Hotels and Jumeirah Hotel Group are also considering expansion into Iran.

David McGuinness, co-founder of specialist tour operator Travel The Unknown told MailOnline Travel how the deal is expected to impact tourism and why now is the perfect time to visit Iran.
He said: 'The nuclear deal opens up new prospects for Iran as a tourist destination.
'People sometimes forget that Iran was one of the oldest tourist destinations, attracting people to its ancient sites before tourism as a concept had really begun to take hold.
Vibrant history: The Jameh Mosque of Yadz is a popular attraction for tourists visiting Iran
The Mosque of Sheikh Lutfullah in Esfahan is intricately decorated with colourful tiles and calligraphy
'Iran has a wealth of attractions - ancient cities like Persepolis and Pasargadae built by famous leaders like Cyrus the Great, and Darius, stunning Islamic art and architecture, reaching its zenith in Esfahan.
'The country is supremely friendly and welcoming country, despite what our preconceptions may lead us to believe. Hospitality is in their blood.
'Now the path forward to a normalisation of relations, while certainly not assured, is beginning to emerge into the light - and with this a rebirth of tourism in Iran,' Mr McGuinness concluded.
A traditional tea house with pools and an elaborate interior where visitors can escape the heat to enjoy refreshments
The high-end train operator Golden Eagle Luxury Trains has expanded its Iran itinerary to take in the varied landscape
Golden Eagle Luxury Trains have organised four rail tours to and from Iran since October last year, and they will be increasing capacity next year, doubling the number of Heart of Persia tours.
Natasha Baker, Sales & Marketing Manager at Golden Eagle Luxury Train s said: 'Boasting more Unesco World Heritage Sites than any other Middle Eastern country, there are few destinations that exude the same entrancing charm as Iran right now.
'Our journeys to Iran on board the luxury Golden Eagle Danube Express train offer a unique insight into this rarely visited and extremely welcoming country, discovering ancient Persia's most remarkable sites including Persepolis, Shiraz, Isfahan and Yazd amongst others.'
Snaking through the hills and mountains of Iran, train tourists can discover a 'unique insight' into the country
History: Iran is packed with ancient ruins, Islamic art and palaces to be discovered
Benjamin Carey, managing director of sustainable tourism consultants, Dunira Strategy told MailOnline Travel that there is a surprising natural diversity in Iran and that it comprises more than just desert.
'Observing turtles hatching on the beaches of Qeshm in the south, skiing down snowy mountains beside the Chalous Road north of Tehran or searching for rare mountain goats in Kolah Ghazi National Park near Esfahan are all possible in Iran,' he said.
Ripe with potential for travellers eager to explore its rich heritage and to discover a vibrant new perspective, here are some of Iran's top tourism highlights.
Persepolis
Persepolis, the ceremonial capital of the Achaemenid kings, which was wasn't recovered until the 1930s
Stunning art: Spectacular reliefs with intricate stone carvings (left) and The Gate of All Nations (right)
The ancient Persian capital, Persepolis was built by Persian emperors from Darius to Xerxes and construction ceased with the downfall of the Achaemenid dynasty.
The earliest remains date back to 515BC and it considered an archaeological gem.
Persepolis was declared a Unesco Heritage Site in 1979.
Esfahan
Meidan-e Emam square with Sheikh Lotfallah Mosque in the background
Esfahan is Iran's number one city for tourists, thanks in no small part to its beautiful Persian gardens, wide tree-lined streets and artisans working in open shops
One of the largest cities in the world, 211 miles south of Tehran, it is described as the pinnacle of Islamic art and architecture.
Esfahan is brimming with palaces, mosques and historic buildings alongside elaborate gardens.
The buzzing city also provides wide-lined streets with markets and shops offering distinctive trinkets and handmade art.
Mount Damavand
At 18,400ft Mount Damavand is a potentially active volcano with the highest peak in Iran
The highest mountain in the Middle East at 18,400ft, Mount Damavand is also Asia's highest volcano.
For visitors to Tehran its summit can be seen in the distance.
It has numerous routes of varying difficulty for climbers and walkers alike throughout the year. There is also a ski resort and it is a popular spot for Middle East winter sports tourism from mid November through to May. Damawand Ski Resort gives enthusiasts the options of wild ski touring, off piste touring and snowboarding.
Alamut Valley
Epic vistas: A sun drenched Alamut Valley is one of Iran's unique landscapes
For those seeking something a little more remote with a sense of real Iranian hospitality there are opportunities to stay in a homestay in Alamut Valley.
The two citadels of Ismailis and castles can be found in this sweeping hilly landscape.
A photogenic backdrop containing Crusader castles founded by the infamous 'Assassins' of the Middle Ages awaits travellers.
Kashan
The historic merchants palace Borujerdi House, Kashan in the Esfahan Province
Offering stately homes, Persian gardens, and a beautiful bazaar Kashan has plenty of attractions for a stopover.
Kashan is internationally famous for manufacturing carpets, silks and other textiles.
Traditional Persian architecture, wind towers and courtyards can be explored at Borujerdi's House in Kashan.
Ancient capitals
Takht-e Madar-e Soleiman, Throne of Solomons Mother, archaeological site of Pasargadae is UNESCO recognised as a World Heritage Site
A jewel in the Middle East with its 19 Unesco World Heritage Sites, Iran has a number of top historical highlights.
Susa (the ancient Elamite capital), Ecbatana (the ancient Achaemenid capital) and the Median capital of Pasargadae built by Cyrus the Great are impressive attractions.
Ecbatana was the summer residence of the Achaemenian kings and one of the residences of the Parthian kings.
The colourful mosques and distinctive architecture of Imam Square in Esfahan
Yazd
The oldest mud-brick city in the world, Yadz is home to the Zoroastrian Fire Temples and Towers of Silence which was used by Zoroastrians for excarnation.
The city is also the scene of beautiful wind badgirs which is an ancient system of air conditioning.
Shiraz
Synonymous with poetry and wine, Shiraz is also known as the city of gardens.
Visitors can explore these outdoor landscapes interspersed with mosques, palaces and a wonderful bazaar..
The shrine of Hazra-e Massoumeh in the holy city of Qom in Iran which is 75 miles south of Tehran
Iranian food
Chicken kebab and rice (left) and Persian rice with cinnamon, bay leaves and almonds (right)
Persians are passionate about food and visitors will find dishes with a strong emphasis on rice, aubergine, grilled meats, pomegranate, walnuts, lime, prunes, cinnamon and saffron.
Picnicking is a favourite pastime amongst Iranians.
Mr Carey said: 'Persian food is unlike anything you have ever tasted. Try Fesenjan, a sublime stew of chicken or pheasant in a rich walnut and pomegranate sauce. The dates, the apricots and of course the grapes of Shiraz. Sheer heaven.'
